derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English hype, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch heup and German Hüfte, also to hop
Old English hēope, hīope, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch joop and German Hiefe
early 20th cent. (originally US): of unknown origin

entry.def: Your hips are the two areas at the sides of your body between the tops of your legs and your waist.

example.ex: Tracey put her hands on her hips and sighed.
example.tran: 特蕾西双手叉腰叹了口气。

entry.def: You refer to the bones between the tops of your legs and your waist as your hips .
If you say that someone is hip, you mean that they are very modern and follow all the latest fashions, for example in clothes and ideas.

example.ex: ...a hip young character with tight-cropped blond hair and stylish glasses.
example.tran: 留着一头毛寸金发、戴着时尚眼镜的时髦青年

entry.tran: （表示欣赏或赞许的呼声）好啊！加油！万岁！
entry.def: If a large group of people want to show their appreciation or approval of someone, one of them says 'Hip hip' and they all shout 'hooray'.

entry.tran: 鲁莽行事;轻举妄动;信口开河
entry.def: If you say that someone shoots from the hip or fires from the hip, you mean that they react to situations or give their opinion very quickly, without stopping to think.

example.ex: Judges don't have to shoot from the hip. They have the leisure to think, to decide.
example.tran: 法官们不必贸然行事。他们可以不慌不忙地去思考，去决定。

means.word_mean: 1. either side of the body below the waist and above the thigh
2. the structure of the vertebrate skeleton supporting the lower limbs in humans and the hind limbs or corresponding parts in other vertebrates
3. the ball-and-socket joint between the head of the femur and the acetabulum
4. the fruit of a rose plant
